Spread, spread your sails with mercy

As you plough the trackless,This line seems to be missing a word that would retain the rhyme and meter of the poem's other stanzas. Perhaps "trackless deep" is intended, as many writers of the period used that formulation to refer to the sea. The American poet Lydia H. Sigourney, for example, uses the phrase in Traits of the Aborigines of America(1822),"To a Fragment of Cotton"(1841), and "Sorrow as on the Sea"(1854).
And at your stern and helm

Your theme Immanuel.Immanuel, from the Hebrew meaning "God is with us" or "may God be with us." The prophet Isaiah announces the birth of a child with the name (Isaiah 7:10-17). Christians would later take the name to predict the virgin birth of the Messiah, Jesus Christ (Matthew 1:22).
An oblationoblation: making a religious offering to God or god; a holy gift offered at an alter or shrine pure and holy
To the God of earth and skies.
He who from the fiery pillar
Shall protect you by his power
As you sweep across the main.
Shall the God of love be with you
May his presence and his power
Be your stay in grief and trial
And the joy of every hour.
